accelerator.desc: Use accelarators to optimize resource utilization and improve response time.

access.desc:
Use Access Restriction to Allow/Deny access to SafeSquid's service for specific user/user groups.

This allows you to specify the Access rights for various users.

Also, it categorizes the users into user groups for being uniquely processed in other sections.

FALSE.desc: Select this to disable profile tracing.

TRUE.desc: Select this if you want to enable profile tracing.

ALLOW.desc: When Policy is set to Allow,a request is allowed access, when no matching entry is found.

DENY.desc: When Policy is set to Deny, a request is denied access, if no matching entry is found.

FALSE.desc: Select this if you DO NOT want to use NTLM Authentication.

TRUE.desc: Select this if you want to use NTLM Authentication

CONFIG.desc: selecting this option will allow the user to access the SafeSquid Web GUI (http://safesquid.cfg). If this option is deselected, the user will be sent an Access Denied template, when he tries to access the web GUI. Note: Access to http://safesquid.cfg/template/(templatename) is always allowed regardless of selecting / deselecting this option.

PROXY.desc: Selecting this option will allow the user to make regular proxy requests.

HTTP.desc: Selecting this option will allow the user to make regular HTTP requests to proxy (for Web interface and redirected requests).

TRANSPARENT.desc: Selecting this option will allow the user to make transparent proxy requests (must be allowed to make HTTP requests as well).

CONNECT.desc: Selecting this option will allow the user to make CONNECT requests for secure connections like HTTPS requests, or use of Internet Applications like FTP or SSH Clients.

BYPASS.desc: Selecting this option will allow the user to use the URL Command xx--bypass to bypass filtering rules. This feature can be used to diagnose filtering reasons, and hence should be selected only for proxy administrators, and not for other users. Note: The URL Commands option below should also be selected, to allow this option.

URLCOMMAND.desc: Selecting this option will allow the user to use URL Commands(except bypass, which needs to be allowed separately). URL Commands allow you to test the functionalities and verify your configurations remotely, from the browser. URL commands can be used to show information about a webpage and to bypass certain features.

HEADER-FILTERING.desc: Selecting this option will bypass Header filtering section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

REDIRECT.desc: Selecting this option will bypass URL redirecting section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

COOKIES-FILTERING.desc: Selecting this option will bypass Cookie filtering section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

REWRITE.desc: Selecting this option will bypass Document rewriting section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

EXTERNAL.desc: Selecting this option will bypass External parsers section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

FORWARD.desc: Selecting this option will bypass Request forwarding section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

KEYWORDS-FILTERING.desc: Selecting this option will bypass Keyword filtering section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

DNSBL.desc: Selecting this option will bypass DNS blacklist section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

LIMITS.desc: Selecting this option will bypass Limits section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

ANTIVIRUS.desc: Selecting this option will bypass Virus scanning for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

ICAP.desc: Selecting this option will bypass ICAP section for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

DLP.desc: Selecting this option will bypass DLP module for the users to whom this policy will get applied.

policy.desc:
You can set your Default Access Policy to either Allow or Deny.

When you set your Default Access Policy as allow, all requests are allowed.

Those that match an entry in the Deny Sub-Section are not allowed.

Conversely, if you set the Default Access Policy set to deny, all requests are blocked.

Those that match an entry in the Allow Sub-Section are not allowed.

Recommended:

If you set the default policy to Deny, you must create entries in the Allow sub-section.

You do this to specify which users should be allowed access.

Conversely, if you set the default policy to Allow, you must create entries in the Deny List Sub-Section.

This is to specify which users should be denied access.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profile_tracing.desc:
Enable or Disable Tracing of this entry

Select "Yes" to debug the application of entry using SafeSquid logs.

Enable entry tracing, is useful if you wish to validate, its application.

ldap_profiles.desc:
When you want to apply this rule, specify the LDAP users/groups/OUs.

When your LDAP Server is integrated with Safesquid only, this can be done.

To integrate your LDAP Server with Safesquid, use Integrate LDAP section.

profiles.desc:
Prepare the list of all Profiles for which this entry should be applicable.

Leave it Blank, if you do not want to carry out this applicability test.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections regardless of their Profiles.

To avoid application of this entry to a connection that has a profile, use negation (! profile)

interface.desc:
When SafeSquid is listening on multiple interfaces, specify here the interface (IP: PORT) that you want this entry to apply to.

Leaving it blank implies to all interfaces (leave it blank if SafeSquid is listening on only one interface).

This can be used to: Allow access to the Web interface (http://safesquid.cfg), only on a specific interface (IP: PORT), to enhance security.

Allow authenticated access on one interface and unauthenticated access to specific websites on another.

Make proxy.pac file at http://safesquid.cfg/template/proxy.pac available for auto proxy script

Make it auto proxy detection on another interface, when only authenticated access is allowed on the primary interface.

ip.desc:
When you want this rule to match, specify the IP Address (es).

If you wish the rule to match a specific IP address, simply specify that IP address.

Alternatively, if you want the rule to be matched for more than one IP address, you can specify a comma separated list of IP addresses.

You can also specify range of IPs.

For E.g.: 192.168.0.10-192.168.0.44, this ensures that all clients with IP address from 192.168.0.10 to 192.168.0.44 will be matched.

If you leave it blank, this rule will apply to all the clients irrespective of their IP Address (es).

If you use in a combination of User name field, matched users are allowed access only from IPs defined in this field.

pamauth.desc:
Enables authentication for users

You are prompted for a username/password by the browser.

Then you have to enter a proper username/password.

username.desc:
If you would want the user(s) to be authenticated, only, fill this field.

It depends on the following conditions:

(a) With No Authentication selected, fill in the user name with which you would like the user to authenticate.

You also have to fill in the Password field for this user.

The user is allowed to access, with the specified User name and Password.

(b) With Pam Authentication selected, fill in existing user name(s) on the server configured for PAM, and leave the Password field blank.

Only users specified in this field are allowed authenticated access.

You can specify multiple user names, separated with pipe, e.g. ^(john|abraham|mary|laurent)$.

If you leave this field blank, authenticated access is allowed to all the users on the authenticating server.

password.desc:
You have to fill in the User name field.

This is the password for the user defined in the User name field.

You are allowed access, if you meet the authentication challenge, by responding with the entry in User name field, and this password.

access.desc: Specify the features that connections matching this entry are allowed to access.

bypass.desc:
Specify the features which you can bypass for connections matching this entry.

To match this entry, specify the features which you can bypass for connections.

ifusername.desc:
You can use this field, along with Interface password, to allow authenticated access to the Web Interface (http://safesquid.cfg).

When you donâ€™t define users, this single entry allows access to everyone, globally.

A user is allowed access to the web interface of SafeSquid, only if he/she meets the authentication challenge, by responding with this User name field, and corresponding Password.

Recommended:

Create a second layer of security, for accessing the Web Interface by creating multiple proxy admin accounts each possessing individual username and password for accessing the Web Interface.

ifpassword.desc:
You must fill this field, only if you have filled in the Interface username field above.

This is the password for the user defined in the Interface username field.

A user is allowed access to the web interface of SafeSquid, if he/she meets the authentication challenge, by responding with this User name, and corresponding Password.

add_user_groups.desc:
Group the users based on the similarities of their profiling that are going to be in the other sections.

If you wish the users defined in this entry can be grouped with any existing groups, simply add those user groups here.

If you wish to create a new user group for these users, give a new name to the new user group.

When defining a new User Group, use terms that uniquely describe the user groups.

max_concurrency.desc:
Set the maximum number of concurrent connections permissible per IP.
Default is 0 (unlimited).

allow.desc:
When the Policy is Deny, requests matching an entry listed in this Allow Sub-Section are exclusively allowed access, denying all the other requests.

The entries are matched in the top-down order, so the entry in the top of a sub-section is matched first.

Then, the first entry that matches is used for the connection, and the remaining entries are ignored.

So, the order of the entries listed is very important.

deny.desc:
When the Default Access Policy is set to Allow, only requests matching an entry listed in this Deny Sub-Section are exclusively denied access, allowing all the other requests.

The entries are matched in the top-down order, so that the entry in the top of a sub-section is matched first, and the first entry that matches is used for the connection, while the remaining entries are ignored.

So the order of the entries listed is very important.

applicationSignatures.desc: This Section allows you to manage SafeSquid's Application Signatures Engine.

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable the use of Application Signatures.

comment.desc: Enter your comments here for future references, explaining what this entry does.

app_signatures.desc: Comma separated list of Request Profiles to which this entry will be applied. This could be one or more Request Profiles already applied(ADDED REQUEST PROFILES) to the connection, due to this entry in the list. If kept Blank, it will apply to all connections irrespective of any applied request profile.

method.desc: This entry applies to requests matching the selected list of Method(s). If this entry should be applied to all requests irrespective of methods do not select any method.

protocol.desc: This entry applies to requests matching the selected list of protocol(s). IF this entry should be applied to all requests irrespective of protocols do not select any protocol.

mime.desc: This entry applies to regular expression matching the MIME-type. Here MIME-type indicates the entity-body sent to the recipient(used with POST and PUT requests). Example: Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded. IF this entry should be applied to all requests irrespective of MIME-type leave it blank.

portrange.desc: Comma separated list of ports or port ranges to which this entry will be applied. Here portrange indicates TCP port(s) number on which the server is listening. Example: value "80,21-25" means port 80 and port range from 21 to 25. Applies to all ports if left blank.

url_commands.desc: Comma separated list of URL command(s) to which this entry will be applied. If this entry should be applied to all requests irrespective of any urlcommand leave it blank.

postdata_min_length.desc: This entry applies only if Request body is more than this size. Example: Content-Length: 48

postdata_max_length.desc: This entry applies only if Request body is less than this size. Example: Content-Length: 480

file.desc: This entry applies to regular expression matching the file portion of requested web-server(the part of a URL that succeeds hostname). Example: (cgi-bin|\?) will apply to queries in a URL. Leave it blank to apply all the requests irrespective of file portion of URI(Uniform Resource Identifier).

registered_domain.desc:
Regular expression matching the Registered domain name of the requested host.
Example:
Registered Domain: ^wikipedia\. will match all sites like wikipedia.org, www.wikipedia.com, en.wikipedia.org, etc.
Leave it blank to apply all the requests irrespective of registered domain.

hostname.desc:
Regular expression matching the FQDN (Fully Qualified Domain Name) of the requested host.
Example:
Host Name: mail\. will match all sites like mail.google.com, www.email.com, etc.
Leave it blank to apply all the requests irrespective of host name.

referer_domain.desc:
Regular expression matching the registered domain of the referrer host.
Example:
Referer Domain Name: ^wikipedia\. will match all requests with referer hostnames like wikipedia.org, www.wikipedia.com, en.wikipedia.org, etc.
Leave it blank to apply all the requests irrespective of referer domain.

referer_host.desc:
Regular expression matching the FQDN (Fully Qualified Domain Name) referrer host.
Example:
Host Name: mail\. will match all requests referred by sites like mail.google.com, www.email.com, etc.
Leave it blank to apply all the requests irrespective of host name.

referer.desc: This entry applies to regular expression matching the referer(the address of the resource from which the requested URI was obtained) of requested web-server. Example: Referer: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page Leave it blank to apply all requests irrespective of referer of header.

user_agent.desc: This entry applies to regular expression matching to a specific internet client or web client(application requesting the information from the server). Example: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:12.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/21.0 Leave it blank to apply all requests irrespective of any application requesting the information from the server.

xforwardedfor.desc: This entry applies to regular expression matching the X-Forwarded-For(the IP address from where the original request came from either proxy or load balancer). Example: X-Forwarded-For: 129.78.138.66, client1, proxy1 . To apply all requests irrespective of X-forwarded-for leave it blank.

requestheader.desc: This entry applies to regular expression matching the request header pattern. Apply to all request patterns if left blank.

add_app_signatures.desc: Comma separated list of Request Profiles that will be added to connection, if the above specified tests result true.

remove_app_signatures.desc: Comma separated list of Request Profiles to be removed when all the above rules match. If any of these Request profiles have been already applied to the connection by any of the other Request Profile rules, they will be removed.

comment.desc: Enter your comments here for future references, explaining what this entry does.

GET.desc: GET method is used to retrieve information from server using a given requested web-server. Requests using GET should only retrieve data and should have no other effect on the data. Select this if you want to apply this entry for requests with GET method.

POST.desc: POST method is used to submit data to be processed (Example: customer information, file upload etc. using HTML forms). The data is included in the body of the request. This may result in the creation of a new resource or the updates of existing resources or both. Select this if you want to apply this entry for requests with POST method.

CONNECT.desc: CONNECT Converts the request connection to a transparent TCP/IP tunnel, usually to facilitate SSL-encrypted communication(HTTPS) through an unencrypted HTTP proxy(e.g. SSL tunnelling). Select this if you want to apply this entry for requests with CONNECT method.

HEAD.desc: HEAD method is identical to GET. However in response to HEAD request server shall not return a message body. Select this if you want to apply this entry for requests with HEAD method.

PUT.desc: PUT method is used to upload a representation of the specified resource. If request for any web-server refers to an already existing resource, it will be modified. Otherwise server can create the resource with present URI(Uniform Resource Identifier). Select this if you want to apply this entry for requests with PUT method. Unused.

DELETE.desc: DELETE method removes the specified resource. It intends to delete the resource or move it to an inaccessible location identified by the requested web-server. Select this if you want to apply this entry for requests with DELETE method. Unused.

TRACE.desc: TRACE Echoes back the received request, so that a client can see what intermediate servers are adding or changing in the request. The final recipient of the request SHOULD reflect the message received back to the client as the entity-body of a 200 (OK) response. Select this if you want to apply this entry for requests with TRACE method. Unused.

OPTIONS.desc: OPTIONS method returns the HTTP methods that server supports for specified URL. OPTIONS can be used to check the functionality of a web server by requesting * instead of a specific resource. Select this if you want to apply this entry for requests with OPTIONS method. Unused.

ftp.desc: File Transfer Protocol(FTP) is a standard network protocol used to transfer files from any host to another host over a TCP-based network. Select this if you want to apply this entry for FTP clients.

http.desc: Hypertext Transfer Protocol(HTTP) is an application protocol for distributed, collaborative, hypermedia information systems. HTTP is the protocol to exchange or transfer hypertext. Select this if you want to apply this entry for HTTP clients.

https.desc: Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) is a communications protocol for secure communication over a computer network. <b>Very first request for HTTPS will be CONNECT request, subsequently it will be changed to HTTPS. Therefore lower down in protocol it is HTTPS request. Select this if you want to apply this entry for HTTP clients who want to access websites using SSL.

app.desc: The following rules are tested for each connection. The testing is done in top-down order. The first entry that matches the Request Profile of a connection, will be applied to it. Click on Add below, to add a new entry.

app_categories_entry.desc: The following rules are tested for each connection. The testing is done in top-down order. The first entry that matches the Request Profile of a connection, will be applied to it. Click on Add below, to add a new entry.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

builtin_cookie_profiles.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

oow.desc: This is a Test entry two.

cache.desc:
You can add/remove cache stores in this section, and configure: Global cache options

What objects are cacheable or un-cacheable?

How cacheable objects are distributed between various stores?

Minimum and maximum size of the objects to be stored

Revalidation period of cached objects, etc

FILLSIZE.desc: select the storage directory with the least total bytes used

FILLPERCENT.desc: select the storage directory with the lowest percentage of space used.

violate_rfc.desc:
This option causes the proxy server to violate some rules in the HTTP RFC to help improve cache performance specifically.

When a website requests that the file must not be cached with the "No-Cache" directive in the Cache-Control header, the proxy caches it anyway but always validates it with an If-Modified-Since conditional request.

maxmemsize.desc:
The maximum size in bytes of the memory cache.

You can enter values in KB,MB,GB as 20K,20M,20G respectively.

memextra.desc:
This is the memory cache size that is emptied, when the content cached in the memory is refreshed.

The stalest content is removed, to free up space for new content.

This prevents frequently used content from being deleted, when the store reaches its maximum allowed limit.

You can enter values in KB,MB,GB as 20K,20M,20G respectively.

minsize.desc: The minimum file size in bytes of any cached file.

maxsize.desc: The maximum file size in bytes of any cached file; if set to 0, no maximum file size is imposed.

prefetchwindow.desc: Use this option to specify the time period after a file is pre-fetched, to exempt from refresh or expiry rules.

icpport.desc: The UDP port to listen for ICP packets on.

icptimeout.desc: The timeout in milliseconds for response ICP packets.

sbalancemethod.desc:
This option controls how the storage directory file is selected.

Fill size selects the storage directory with the least total bytes used.

Fill percent selects the storage directory with the lowest percentage of space used.

journalsize.desc: The maximum size in bytes of the journal.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (!profile).

path.desc: Path of the directory where cached files are stored.

maxdisksize.desc:
The amount of space that should be used to store cached files in this directory.

You can enter values in KB,MB,GB as 20K,20M,20G respectively.

diskextra.desc:
This is the size of the cache store that is emptied, when the content in the store is refreshed.

The stalest content is removed, to free up space for new content.

This prevents frequently used content from being deleted, when the store reaches its maximum allowed limit.

The value here is normally set to 30% of the total size of the store. e.g. when Maximum Disk Size is 1G, then the value entered here would be 250M.

md5.desc:
Perform MD5 check on cache files when saving them and loading them from disk.

With this you can ensure that the corrupted cache files are not used.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (!profile).

cachable.desc: Whether or not requests matching this entry are cached.

minage.desc: The minimum age of any file according to the Last-Modified header. Only files older than this age are cached.

maxage.desc:
The maximum age of any cached file before it must be revalidated.

This overrides any given expiry time.

validate.desc:
The maximum age of any cached file which doesn't include any headers that indicate, when it should expire before it must be revalidated;

if set to 0, all cached files whose expiry time is uncertain are verified.

If no "Last-Modified" header is received to calculate the Last-Modified time factor, the cached file is always revalidated.

lmfactor.desc:
The maximum age of any cached file which doesn't include any headers that indicate when it should expire before it must be revalidated;

if set to 0, all cached files whose expiry time is uncertain are verified.

If no "Last-Modified" header is received to calculate the Last-Modified time factor, the cached file is always revalidated.
