store.desc: List of storage locations for disk cache.

category_editor.desc:
Use Categorize websites to Manage Web-Site Categorization.

Review and modify the categorization of any website.

You can also create new categories, and associate websites with those categories.

To Modify a web-site's categorization, you must first use the search box to view its existing categorization.

It will show you the details of Total Number of Categories, Last updated and last changed.

template.category_template:
Total categories

Last changes by

Last update time

Search for category
Upload websites file
Categories

You can add,delete,modify categories

category.desc:
Here you can edit or modify the previously existed category of any website.

Search for category: Here you can find the category of any website in which it is categorized.

Enter the name of the website in the search box, then it will show the list of categories in which it is categorized.

Upload websites file: Here you can upload a file, which contains the list of websites and adds the category to those websites.

Example: search for yahoo.com.It will display: news, portals, search engines

Make one text file with the list of websites and Upload that file and add the category. Then check the website from that file by searching its category, following which, it shows the category added by you.

clamav.desc: With this antivirus feature you can detect and block files containing viruses known to the ClamAV daemon scanner.

clamavhost.desc: Specify the host on which ClamAV daemon is running or path, to its local socket.

clamavport.desc:
Specify Port of ClamAV daemon.

Leave it blank if you are using local socket. The default port will be 3310.

dtempl.desc:
You can send name of the Template, when this entry is matched

Leave it blank for Default template.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections, irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (!profile).

templ.desc: Specify the name of the template to be sent, when this entry is matched.

configure.desc: Configure SafeSquid to serve your internet access policies.

contentSignatures.desc: This Section allows you to manage SafeSquid's response profiling engine.

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable the use of content signatures.

comment.desc: Enter your comments here for future references, explaining what this entry does.

valueField.desc: This entry applies to regular expression matching the MIME-type. Here MIME-type indicates the response-body received from the server. Example: Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8 IF this entry should be applied to all responses irrespective of MIME-type leave it blank.

add_content_signatures.desc: List of Response Profiles that will be added to connection, if the above specified tests result true.

comment.desc: Enter your comments here for future references, explaining what this entry does.
Enter your comments here for future references, explaining what this entry does.

valueField.desc: This entry applies to regular expression matching the extension of file(s) obtained in response body. Leave it blank to apply all the requests irrespective of file extension.

add_file_extensions.desc: List of Response Profiles that will be added to connection, if the above specified tests result true.

false.desc: Select this if you don\'t want to apply profile if transfer encoding chunked present in response header.

true.desc: Select this if you want to apply profile if transfer encoding chunked present in response header.

any.desc: Select this if transfer encoding chunked does not matter in response header.

false.desc: Select this if you don\'t want to apply profile if multipart/ byteranges present in response header.

true.desc: Select this if you want to apply profile if multipart/ byteranges present in response header.

any.desc: Select this if multipart/ byterange does not matter in response header.

false.desc: Select this to disable profile tracing.

true.desc: Select this to enable profile tracing.

content_entry.desc: The following rules are tested for each connection. The testing is done in top-down order. The first entry that matches the Response Profile of a connection, will be applied to it. Click on Add below, to add a new entry.

content_categories_entry.desc: The following rules are tested for each connection. The testing is done in top-down order. The first entry that matches the Request Profile of a connection, will be applied to it. Click on Add below, to add a new entry.

content_file_extensions_entry.desc: The following rules are tested for each connection. The testing is done in top-down order. The first entry that matches the Request Profile of a connection, will be applied to it. Click on Add below, to add a new entry.

cookies-filtering.desc:
With Cookie Filter you can choose, which hosts (websites,) the browsers are allowed to send and receive the cookies.

A HTTP cookie (also called as web cook0ie, Internet cookie, browser cookie or simply cookie) is a small piece of data sent from a website and stored in the user's web browser while the user is browsing.

You can control the cookie exchange precisely, between remote websites and users.

You can manage the user privacy (Username & Preferences).

You can also disable the users from logging into their personal accounts.

Example: you can block cookies from advertising websites like tribalfusion.com and doubleclick.net to prevent private information from being transferred to them.

And users can browse the search engines (google, yahoo) but they cannot login to their personal accounts (Gmail, shopping websites, trading websites).

ALLOW.desc: When Policy is set to Allow, a requested cookie is allowed, when no matching entry is found

DENY.desc: When Policy is set to Deny, a requested cookie is denied, if no matching entry is found

BOTH.desc: For Both Inbound and Outbound connections.

ABSOLUTETIME.desc: When the absolute time match mode is used, any time between the starting and ending time will match. For example, if a start time of 9am monday and end time of 5pm friday is given, in absolute time match mode any time between 9am monday and 5pm friday will match.

ALLRANGES.desc: With the all ranges time match mode however, a time within all of the ranges will match. For example, if a start time of 9am monday and end time of 5pm friday is given, With all range time match mode, any time between 9am and 5pm, monday to friday will match.

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable cookie filtering section.

policy.desc: Select the default action to take, when no matching entry for a requested cookie is found.

comment.desc:
Explain the relevance of this entry with your policies, for documentation, and future references.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (! profile).

year.desc:
Mention the cookie expiry year range that is relevant to this entry.

The cookie from a particular host (website) expires after this range.

Ex: 2016-2017

month.desc:
Select cookie expiry month range that is relevant to this entry.

The cookie from a particular host (website) expires after this range.

Example: January â€“ March, here cookie expires after March.

day.desc:
The cookie expiry day range that is relevant to this entry.

The cookie from a particular host (website) expires after this range.

Example: 1-20, here cookie will expire after 20th day.

weekday.desc:
The cookie expiry weekday range, this entry applies to.

The cookie from a particular host (website) expires after this range.

Example: Monday â€“ Friday, here cookie will expire after Friday.

hour.desc:
The cookie expiry hour range, this entry applies to.

The cookie from a particular host (website) expires after this range.

Example: 1-10, here cookie will expire after 10AM.

minute.desc:
The cookie expiry minute range, this entry applies to.

The cookie from a particular host (website) expires after this range.

Example: 15-30, here cookie will expire after 10:30AM.

In the above example, Hours are included from Hour range.

domain.desc:
you can mention the domain names by separating with pipe (|) which you want to allow or deny.

You can use regular expression to match the domains.

Ex: safesquid.com|google.com

path.desc:
A regular expression matching the cookie's path attribute.

Ex: /

direction.desc: The direction of the cookie this entry applies to; can be either in (Set-cookie sent by website), out (Cookie sent by browser), or both.

matchmode.desc: Select the appropriate mode to match the multiple time ranges.

allow.desc:
When the Policy is Deny, rules defined under this sub-section, are exclusively allowed access.

Here you can add a new â€˜allowâ€™ entry, that would explicitly result in acceptance or allowance of cookie transfer to all or specific set of conditions.

This effectively allows you set a variety of intelligently and creatively defined Cookie Transfer whitelist(s)

deny.desc:
When the Policy is Allow, rules defined under this sub-section, are exclusively denied access.

Here, you can add rules under Deny that would explicitly result in blocking or denial of cookie transfer to all or specific set of conditions.

This effectively allows you to set a variety of intelligently and creatively defined Cookie Transfer Blacklist(s).

dnsbl.desc: <dl> <dt>DNS Blacklist</dt> <dd>Use DNS to detect client requests to inappropriate or malicious servers.</dd> <dd>Prevent requests to IP addresses of malicious servers</dd> </dl>

GS.desc: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable the use of DNS Blacklist.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

bl_categories.desc:
Requested hosts belonging to this category list shall be considered threatful.

Requests to such hosts, shall be blocked without any DNS evalution.

bl_requests.desc:
Requested hosts belonging to this request type list shall be considered threatful.

Requests to such hosts, shall be blocked without any DNS evalution.

bl_countries.desc:
Requested hosts belonging to this country list shall be considered threatful.

Requests to such hosts, shall be blocked after DNS evalution.

domain.desc:
This field needs to be filled in, only for making query to a DNSBL service.

The website to query is appended with DNSBL Domain name.

For example: If you set DNSBL Domain .in.dnsbl.org, then a host such as example.com, is validated with a DNS lookup for A records of example.com.in.dnsbl.org

badips.desc:
Enter the comma separated list of IP address ranges that should be considered threatful.

The requested host is considered threatful if the DNS query results an IP address contained in this list.

DNS query failures are equivalent to 0.0.0.0.
Therefore, include 0.0.0.0 in this list if you want to block requests to hosts when queries to DNSBL services fail.

templ.desc:
Name of the template to be sent, when domain is found to be blocked.

Leave this blank, to use default Template "blocked".

policy.comment: DNS and IP Black Listing Policies
policy.desc: <dl> <dd> Requested Host will be evaluated against Enabled entries. </dd> <dd> Evaluation is done from top to last until an entry results in blocking of the requested host. </dd> </dl>

external.desc:
The external feature allows you to use any program or script to parse the contents of a file.

The external parser must send a complete HTTP request or response header, which overrules the ones sent by the browser or Web server.

If nobody is sent after the header, the original body with modified headers is used.

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable external applications section.

comment.desc:
p>For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc: Comma separated List of Profiles to which this entry will be applied. Leave it Blank to apply to all.

exec.desc: The path to the executable; if no absolute path is given, the path as given in the PATH environment variable is searched. Any number of arguments can be passed by separating them by spaces; if you're using a temporary file as the method to pass the contents of the file, it's path will be the last argument. If an executable returns with a non-zero status code, the original content is returned.

type.desc: The method in which content is passed to the external program; if set to Pipe the content is piped to the program's STDIN, if set to File the content is stored in a temporary file and it's path is passed as the last argument.

flags.desc: Select whether the external application is used on the request, response or both

persession.desc: Run external parser for every request in a session until it returns a non-zero status code, this is useful for performing authentication through an external program.

sendheader.desc: Which header(s), if any, to send to the external program before sending the body. The response header option only applies to external programs that process the response. If both headers are sent, the request header is sent first.

PIPE.desc: The data will be passed to the external program by writing to STDIN.

FILE.desc: The data will be passed to the external program by writing it to a temporary file and passing the filename as the last argument.

REQUEST.desc: Send the request header before the body.

RESPONSE.desc: Send the response header before the body.

REQUESTS.desc: This external program will be used on requests. An external program used on requests may modify the request by sending a request header and possibly a request body for POST or PUT requests, it may also satisfy the request by sending back a response header and possibly a body.

RESPONSES.desc: This external program will be used on responses. An external program used on responses may modify the response by sending a response header and possibly a body.

external.desc: List of external parsers to process content with.

filter.desc: Setup controls to ensure safe information exchange between users and remote websites.

forward.desc:
The Proxy chain section allows you to forward requests through another proxy selectively, SOCKS4 or SOCKS5 firewalls.

You can also use ICP (Internet Cache Protocol) and CARP (Cache Array Routing Protocols) to share cache with peer or sibling proxies.

NONE.desc: The ICP protocol will not be used with this proxy.

PARENT.desc: This proxy is a Parent, when no peer has the cached file it will still be requested from a parent so that it is cached for other peer proxy servers.

SIBLING.desc: This proxy is a Sibling, files are requested from it only when it has a cached copy.

HTTP.desc: This is a HTTP proxy server.

CONNECT.desc: The CONNECT method will be used through the HTTP proxy.

HTTP.desc: This proxy will be used for HTTP requests.

FTP.desc: This proxy will be used for FTP requests.

CONNECT.desc: This proxy will be used for CONNECT requests.

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable proxy chain section.

carp.desc: CARP is a protocol used by a cluster of proxies to have them act as one logical cache by using a hash algorithm which combines the proxy's hostname and requested URL to determine which proxy server the URL is requested from, and thus cached on.

carphashsize.desc: Specify the maximum value of the CARP hash; the lower the value, the greater the redundancy of cached files across peer proxies. Set to 0 for maximum size. Any value other than 0 breaks compatibility with Squid, and all peer proxies must use the same size hash.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (!profile).

proxy.desc:
Specify the hostname or IP address of the proxy to forward through.

If this field is left blank, and the host or file options aren't, no action is taken for requests matching the host and file.

If the Proxy is the same as the server's own hostname, the entry is ignored.

This makes it easier to have a configuration file shared between several proxy servers.

username.desc: Specify the user name to use if the proxy requires authentication.

password.desc: Specify the password to use if the proxy requires authentication.

domain.desc: Specify the NT domain when using the NTLM authentication protocol.

port.desc: Specify the port number of the proxy to forward through.

icptype.desc: The peering relationship of this proxy.

icpport.desc: Specify the UDP port ICP packets are sent to.

type.desc: Specify the type of the proxy; can be HTTP, SOCKS4, SOCKS5 or CONNECT.

which.desc: Specify the type of requests that are forwarded through the proxy; Can be HTTP, FTP and/or CONNECT (HTTPS).

forward.desc: List of proxy servers to forward connections to.

ftp.desc:
FTP Browsing section lets you configure how the FTP connections are established, and results are displayed.

SafeSquid can provide support for browsing FTP Servers, anonymously.

This can be useful when the client (some of the older web-browsers) applications lack the support to directly access FTP sites.

Such Internet Clients may also set SafeSquid as their HTTP/1.1 Proxy to access FTP sites.

The settings made here apply to all requests for ftp: // URLs.

passive.desc:
When you are behind a firewall, it prevents the FTP server from opening a data connection to you.

Thus, it prevents the FTP transfers.

Enabling Passive mode solves this by opening up both (Command and Data) channels from your side.

So, it is recommended to use Passive mode when you are behind a firewall.

timeout.desc: The timeout to wait for a response to commands sent to the FTP server.

anonlogin.desc: Specify the username to be used when none is given in the URL, explicitly

anonpass.desc: The password to be used when none is given in the URL, explicitly

sortorder.desc: Specify the order by which FTP directory listings should be sorted.

sortfield.desc: Specify the field by which FTP directory listings should be sorted.

general.desc:
Use 'System configuration' to tune various parameters with respective network infrastructure.

By this tuning you can improve overall Internet service performance and manage your secure port utilization.

FALSE.desc: Never Request Compressed data from remote web-server.

TRUE.desc: Always Request Compressed data from remote web-server.

AUTO.desc: Request Compressed data from remote web-server ONLY if supported by client.

NONE.desc: Do not send debugging headers to client or server

BOTH.desc: Send debugging headers to both client and server

FALSE.desc: Apply only the Categories associated with the Requested URL

TRUE.desc: Append Custom Categories applicable to the Referring Web-Page to the Categories associated with the Requested URL

ENCODED.desc: Buffer only Encoded (compressed) Chunked Responses if demanded by a content inspector.

ALWAYS.desc: Always Buffer Chunked Responses if demanded by a content inspector.

hostname.desc:
When your enterprise has multiple instances of SafeSquid, various instances will identify each other by this 'Proxy hostname'.

If your enterprise maintains single LDAP domain, then set proxy hostname parameter as 'your LDAP domain'.

Then you can login over LDAP authentication without mentioning the domain.

poolsize.desc:
Set the maximum concurrent outbound connections.

SafeSquid can reuse an established outbound connection, from the Connection Pool.

Connection Pool Size should be at least equal to anticipated concurrent requests,Minimally

If the Connection Pool is full, SafeSquid will automatically delete the oldest connection, to accommodate a new outbound connection.

pooltimeout.desc:
You can set here the maximum time period in seconds, that a connection may be kept in the connection pool.

The age of a connection is reset every-time it gets used.

When the age of a connection exceeds the timeout specified here, it will be automatically removed from the pool.

dheaders.desc:
Vital debugging information like application of profiling and filtering policies can be included in the HTTP protocol headers.
Specify if this information should be sent to client, server, or both.
Leave the field empty if this information should not be sent at all.

catreferer.desc:
The requested URL is normally considered for categorization purposes.
However, when accessing a web page, Internet Browsers may require connecting to various other URLs to complete the portrayal of the web-page.
Requests to these dependency URLs may thus get differently categorized than the originally requested web-page.
Thus even if the initially requested URL is included in a "Custom Category" created by you, and permitted for access, the proxy users may witness "broken pages".
Providing a satisfactory web-experience to the users, thus requires identification and explicit access permission for each of such dependency URL.

Dynamic Categorization determines requests made by Internet Browser to serve a web-page included in a Custom Category.
Custom Categories applicable to the "Referring Web-Page" are added to the list of categories determined for the requested URL.

Dynamic Categorization enables a holistic web-experience to the users, when accessing permitted web-sites.

general.desc:
The following entries will be applied on each connection based on the profiles defined.

Policy evaluation is done in top-down order. The first entry matching the profile will be applied to the connection.

pool.desc: View information of the current connection(s) that are being held open in the connection pool and/or awaiting reuse.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (! profile).

ctimeout.desc:
You can specify maximum time in seconds, for safesquid to wait for the establishment of connection.

This affects the outbound connections made by SafeSquid.

Example:

If you have a slow Internet Connection.

Create a profile for slow to connect web-sites, and select them by increasing this timeout value.

timeout.desc:
Depending upon your network conditions, a significant amount of time may pass between the events of connection set up and the receipt of initial headers from the client.

The timeout in seconds to wait for a client to make the initial HTTP request.

The default value of "5" seconds may not be enough when used by ISPs to service dial-up customers.

keeptimeout.desc:
SafeSquid can keep a connection established with a client, in a client pool. Thus, it can quickly respond to further requests from such clients.

You can specify here in seconds, the maximum time for which the connection may be held at the pool.

maxdbuffer.desc:
Some of the SafeSquid\'s functions like keyword filtering, content rewrite, image filter, virus scanning, etc. require content to be downloaded for processing.

SafeSquid buffers such content, and then passes then to the relevant processors. You can specify here, the maximum size of the downloaded content that may be buffered, and therefore processed. You may use units (K) kilobytes, (M) Megabytes

maxubuffer.desc:
The maximum size of uploads that are buffered for processing, larger uploads will be sent directly to the Web server without processing.

Having an upload buffer that is too large will cause the browser to timeout since all the data is received by safesquid immediately, but may take more time to process and transfer to the website.

bufferwait.desc:
When the content is being buffered, the client may be sent an intimation of the downloading status.

SafeSquid can automatically send the template "downloading", when the content is being downloaded into the buffer. You can specify, the time interval in seconds, at which the downloading template will be resent.

cportrange.desc:
SafeSquid can be used by applications that support, like FTP-clients and other utilities to make "CONNECT", requests. CONNECT over HTTP allows these applications to create a direct tunnel for the required target services.

The specification may be done as a port range. For example - 20,21,1023-65535.

Caution:
The data exchanged by CONNECT protocol cannot be buffered, and therefore analyzed for filtering purposes.

encodemime.desc: A regular expression matching the MIME-types which should always be buffered and compressed even if they would not be buffered otherwise.

compressout.desc:
SafeSquid can compress data using gzip compression, before sending data to clients.

This can significantly boost throughput if SafeSquid is being used as remotely hosted solution.

For networks wherein SafeSquid is deployed locally, it is recommended you disable this feature.

compressin.desc:
This option will make Safesquid attach an Accept-Encoding header that lets the Web server know we can accept gzip and deflate content encodings regardless of whether or not the browser making the request supports it

If the browser doesn't support it, it will be buffered and decompressed before sending.

buffer_chunked.desc:
Buffering Chunked Responses is generally never advisable.
Unfortunately however, real-time content inspection requires buffering of response payload.
Therefore under certain conditions, if you have no choice, you may want to buffer chunked responses.
Select one of the options very wisely.
Recommended and default is FALSE.

xforwardedfor.desc:
This option will add a header letting an upstream proxy or Web server know the IP address where the original request came from.

This feature must be enabled if you are deploying SafeSquid as an ISP based solution.

via.desc:
This option will add a header letting an upstream proxy or Web server know what proxy server the request passed through.

This feature must be enabled if you are deploying SafeSquid as an ISP based solution.

header-filtering.desc:
Here, you can control how the SafeSquid edits the HTTP header messages that pass between your browser and the Internet.

You can increase internet usage privacy levels.

Control the client requests and web server responses.

You can add, delete or modify the Request and Response headers based on their content.

Apart from allowing or denying request or response headers, you can also use Insert sub-section to add a new header or to modify them.

This section analyzes:
Request header patterns that are passed from browsers to webservers.
Response header patterns that are coming from webservers to clients.

ALLOW.desc: Allow everything Except rules defined under Deny sub section.

DENY.desc: Deny everything Except rules defined under Allow sub section.

CLIENT.desc: This entry will be applied only for request headers, sent by the client.

SERVER.desc: This entry will be applied only for response headers, sent by the server.

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable header filter section.

policy.desc: Select the default action to take, when no matching entry for a requested header is found.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections, irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (! profile).

type.desc:
A regular expression matching the header type to which this entry applies to.

Headers are in the form of type and value.

Leave blank to match everything.

Example: X-GoogApps-Allowed-Domains.

value.desc:
A regular expression matching the header values this entry applies to.

Leave blank to Match everything.

Example: text/html.

which.desc: This option is to select whether this entry applies to the server header, client header, or both.

allow.desc:
When the Policy is Deny, rules defined under this sub-section, are allowed access, exclusively.

Here, you can add a new â€˜allowâ€™ entry that would result in acceptance or allowance of header filter to all or specific set of conditions, explicitly.

deny.desc:
When the Policy is Allow, rules defined under this sub-section, are denied access, exclusively.

Here you can add a new â€˜allowâ€™ entry that would explicitly result in blocking or denying the header filter to all or specific set of conditions.

insert.desc:
In this sub section you can add the rules to modify the request and response headers.

You can insert additional information in the headers sent by your browser.

headers.desc: In this sub section you can find the example headers with type and values.

infrastructure.desc:
Setup your Secure Web Gateway.

Most of these configuration options are best done during initial application setup.

keywords-filtering.desc:
Text Analyzer allows you to detect and block the access to websites that may contain inappropriate or pornographic content based on keyword scoring system.

Text analyzer is particularly useful in detecting unclassified websites that could serve inappropriate content.

This feature can be effectively used to block websites belonging to specific category, without having to depend on any database.

When a keyword from the list of words specified in an entry is found, the page is given the score specified in that entry. The total score of the page is equal to the sum of the score of all the rules that matches.

When the total score is equal to or greater than the threshold, then the page is blocked.

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable text analyzer section.

threshold.desc: The number the total score must equal or exceed until it's blocked.

templ.desc:
Templates are used throughout Safesquid as a replacement for pages which can't be displayed due to filtering, error, or other conditions.

Specify the template name that should be displayed on a user's screen when this entry matches. The name should be selected from the template section. In template section you can find templateâ€™s name.

Leave this rule blank, to use default template.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (! profile).

mime.desc:
It's a way of identifying files on the Internet according to their nature and format.

It is highly advisable that you set this to some mime-type; otherwise all files will be checked.

A regular expression matching the mime-types this entry policy applies to.

Example: text/html, ^image/, ^application/, application/x-shockwave-flash.

keyword.desc:
A regular expression matching anything in the body of the document considered inappropriate, leave blank to match everything.

We can add more than one keyword in a single policy.

Example: (sex|sexy|porn|pornography).

score.desc:
This entry adds to the total score when it matches, this may be a positive or negative integer.

If you mention keyword as adult, then every time this word is found in the document, the score mentioned will be added.

Example: If you mentioned score as 20, then if the word adult is found once in the requested document, 20 will be added, for two times it will be 40, three times it will be 60.

keyword.desc:
Here you can add the new policies to block the websites based on content type.

You can give the score to each policy and the keywords to block the inappropriate content.

ldap.desc:
Integrate with Microsoft Active Directory or OpenLDAP.

SafeSquid can also use the Directory Server for authenticating the users.

This will be useful specially when a user cannot be authenticated via Kerberos/SSO.

FALSE.desc: Select this for simple LDAP communications.

TRUE.desc: Select this for SSL based LDAP communications.

SIMPLE_LDAP_AUTH.desc: Select this, if your Directory Server supports Simple LDAP Authentication.

NTLM_LDAP_AUTH.desc: Select this, if your Directory Server supports NTLM based LDAP Authentication.

NEGOTIATE_LDAP_AUTH.desc: Select this, if your Directory Server supports Negotiate based LDAP Authentication.

UserPrincipalName.desc:
The User Principal Name (UPN) is an Internet-style login name for the user based on the Internet standard RFC 822.
The user logon name format is: UserName@DomainName.com.

sAMAccountname.desc:
The samAccountName attribute is the user logon name used to support clients and servers from a previous version of Windows ( Pre-Windows 2000).
The user logon name format is: DomainName\UserName.

uid.desc:
The UID attribute associated with users in a Directory Service.
It may be a simple string (such as username), or look like an email address (such as username@department.domain.com), that reflects part of the organizational hierarchy.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

ldaphost.desc:
In a network with multiple LDAP Servers, and multiple SafeSquid Proxy Servers deployed in Master-Slave mode, this field can be used to specify the Host Name of the Proxy Server, which will communicate with the LDAP Server configured.


Leave this field blank if this is the only SafeSquid proxy, or if you want all the proxies to communicate with the LDAP server configure.

ldapip.desc:
Enter FQDN of LDAP Server.

Use IP address of LDAP Server if user can't go for negotiate authentication.

For Kerberos SSO(single sign on) setup specify value like FQDN\IP (Ex:'ubuntu.safesquid.test\192.168.XX.XX') and select 'Negotiate' bind type.

ldapport.desc: Specify the Port for LDAP service. Usually this would be 389.

ldapssl.desc:
Communicate with LDAP service using TLS protocol by coping LDAP service CA certificate into security directory and rename CA certificate to LDAP_CA_FILE.cer file.


Note: If you do not wish to verify server certificate then do not mention CA certificate. SafeSquid will perform SSL with out requesting server certificate.

ldapmethod.desc: Choose the method for binding (authenticating) with your Directory Server accoring to appropriate binding mechanisms.

ldaplimit.desc: Specify the maximum number of records that should be fetched in a single LDAP query.

ldapuserfilter.desc:
SafeSquid will apply LDAP user filter to narrow the scope of entries requested, to search the users in the LDAP.


By default configuartion, LDAP server will return only entries that necessarily match the requirement of objectclass=person and also have atleast one of the attributes of UserPrincipalName or sAMAccountname or uid set.

ldapgroupfilter.desc: Specify the LDAP Group Filter. This is required if the LDAP server does not support Reverse Group Membership. Note: Microsoft Windows AD server normally supports Reverse Group Membership. Legacy OpenLDAP implementations may not have support for Reverse Group Membership. If the LDAP server supports Reverse Group Membership then leave this field blank. SafeSquid will apply this filter to narrow the scope of entries requested, to search the groups in the LDAP. For example if: LDAP Group Filter: (|(objectclass=posixGroup)(objectclass=groupofNames)) and, Group Identifier: member,members,memberof SafeSquid will construct filter: (|(objectclass=posixGroup)(objectclass=groupofNames)) and set member, members, memberof as the attributes that may be returned in the ldap search queries. Thus LDAP server will return only entries that necessarily match the requirement of objectclass=posixGroup or objectclass=groupofNames. The DN of the resulting entries will be considered as Groups and values assigned to attributes of member or members or memberof as the users belonging to the respective Groups.

ldapusername.desc: Enter the any one Username to bind LDAP Server. Most OpenLDAP servers allow binding anonymosly. In such cases you may leave this blank. For Microsoft AD Servers specify a UserPrincipalName (username@domain.com) or sAMAccountname (Username)

ldappassword.desc: Enter the Encrypted Password for the above username to bind to Microsoft AD or LDAP Server. When you click on 'Utilities', you will be presented with a dropdown menu on the left side of the UI. Select 'Encrypt Password' section. For example - Test1 is an user present in Microsoft AD Servers.Enter same password for user Test1, encrypt the password, and copy the encrypted password.

ldapbasedn.desc: Enter the Basedn of the LDAP Server in Ldap format. For example, for a domain test1.testdomain1.com, enter dc=testdomain1,dc=com

ldapdomain.desc: Specify the LDAP Domain name, for the users that must be authenticated as users of this LDAP server. If you have multiple LDAP servers, SafeSquid will select the appropriate LDAP server to identify and validate a user, by using this as the identifier. For example if you set: LDAP Domain: somedomain.com then all users who present their credentials as username@somedomain.com will be identified and validated from this LDAP server. Note: setting this is extremely important particularly if you are using multiple LDAP servers.

ldaploginattr.desc:
Specify the attributes of a user's entry in LDAP server, that can be permitted for being used for validating user's credentials. Any or all attributes that will be unique for each user in the LDAP server, can be specified here.
SafeSquid extracts the user's DN using these attributes, and uses the DN, and the user's supplied password to bind with the LDAP server.
For example if you could set:
Login Attributes: sAMAccountname,uid,UserPrinicipalName,mail and thus allow your users to use their sAMAccountname or uid or UserPrinicipalName or emailid for the purpose of authentication and profiling. Specifying Attributes that may not be supported by the LDAP server is permissible, though not effective. Note: the list of Login Attributes is comma separated, and unnecessary spaces must be removed.

ldapgroupid.desc:
Specify the LDAP Attributes that may be used to as Group Identifiers identify a user's group membership. For example: Group Identifiers: member,memberof,members,memberuid,memberid,uniquemember If Reverse Group Membership has been implemented on the LDAP server the values assigned to these attributes for a user, will be considered as their group memberships. In such cases the entries resulting in the LDAP query for user search, on the basis of Login Attributes all values assigned to the specified Group Identifiers will be considered as groups to which the user subscribes to.
Typically in case of Microsoft AD, you could have left the text box for Group Filter empty, and values assigned to memberof attributes would have been considered as the user's groups. Legacy implementations of OpenLDAP does not support Reverse Group Membership by default. In such case you would have specified an appropriate value in the Group Filter text box. SafeSquid would then be ale to extract all the entries in LDAP that qualify as Groups. Then the values assigned to the attributes listed in the Group Filter for each of the entries would be considered as users belonging to these Groups. Note: Specifying Attributes that may not be supported by the LDAP server is harmless, though not effective.&  The list of Group Identifier is comma separated, and unnecessary spaces must be removed.

ldapsection.desc:
Define your LDAP server entries here.

Users from all the enabled entries will be fetched by SafeSquid and can be viewed in 'View LDAP cache'.

show_ldap.desc: View list of LDAP entries that are fetched by SafeSquid from the LDAP service(s) configured.

limits.desc: Set data transfer rate (speed or QoS) limits.

ALLOW.desc: Connections will be allowed after matching this entry.

DENY.desc: Connections will be denied after matching this entry.

LIMITCACHE.desc: Transfer limit will be applied even if the content is being served from the cache.

PERREQUEST.desc: Transfer limit will be applied to each single request.

GROUPLIMIT.desc: Transfer bandwidth limit will be shared between all matching connections.

enabled.desc: Enable or Disable limits section to apply data transfer rate (speed or QoS) limits.

comment.desc: Enter your comments here for future references, explaining what this entry does.

profiles.desc:
Select the previously created profiles, to which this rule will be applied.
Leave this rule blank, when you want to apply this entry to all connections.

action.desc:
Select the appropriate action to apply when this entry matches.

For example: Select allow if you desire to set a limit on data transfer or the number of requests that can be made. When limit is reached action will be denied automatically.
If action is set to deny then any request falling into the specified time range will be blocked, otherwise request is allowed.

templ.desc:
Specify the template name that should be displayed on a user's screen when this entry matches.

Leave this rule blank, to use default template "blocked".

For example: Templates like maxbandwidth and maxrequests are used for excessive bandwidth or requests, respectively.

maxdownloadbytes.desc:
Specify the maximum number of bytes(download limit) that can be downloaded by the proxy during the time span of this matching entry.
No download limit is applied, if left blank.

maxuploadbytes.desc:
Specify the maximum number of bytes(upload limit) that can be uploaded by the proxy during the time span of this matching entry.
No upload limit is applied, if left blank.

maxrequests.desc:
Specify the maximum number of requests(maximum request) that would be allowed during the specified time.
No request limit is applied, if left blank.

downloadrate.desc:
Specify the maximum download transfer rate(download rate) that should be allowed.
No download transfer rate will be applied, if left blank.

flags.desc:
Select one or more options affecting how transfer limits should be applied to fine tune the rule.

Transfer Limits will apply:
  • Limit cache transfers: When the content is being served from the cache.
  • Per-request limit: Will be applied to each single request.
  • Group limit: Share transfer limit between all matching connections.

For example:
When download transfer limit is set as 5 MB.
For Per-request limit each and every matching request will be allowed 5 MB.
For Group limit 5 MB will be shared between all the matching connections.

limit.desc:
The list of entries below will be processed from top to down.
Each entry describes limitations on users for accessing content from the Internet.
Disable entries, to ignore them.
Every entry that matches the connection parameters specified in the entry will be processed for that connection.

network.desc:
Configure the basic Network Infrastructure.

Configure the Sockets on which SafeSquid will Listen, and accept connections from clients.

Manage SafeSquid's outgoing connections through existing IPs of your host system.

SSL_TRANSPARENT.desc: Accept SSL requests in transparent mode.

SSL_AUTHENTICATION.desc: User authentication via SSL client certificates. (Not yet implemented)

SSL_BRIDGE.desc: If SafeSquid has been setup as Reverse Proxy, and must provide SSL for non-SSL HTTP servers. (Not yet implemented)

CAPTIVE_PORTAL.desc: Setup a captive portal for user authentication, when SafeSquid is used as a transparent proxy.

listen.desc:
Setup SafeSquidâ€™s Listen Interfaces to accept connections from clients.

When SafeSquid starts-up, all the enabled entries will be evaluated, and create appropriate Listening Sockets.

You may specify these Interfaces when creating policies in Access Restrictions Section.

Evaluation logically skips disabled Entries.

Service restart is required to effect any changes made here.

interface.desc:
Specify Interfaces for outgoing connections.

SafeSquid can take advantage of multiple ISPs or outbound connection routes, on multi-homed host systems.

Create multiple entries as required.

SafeSquid evaluates all enabled entries starting from top, and selects the first one that matches the connection.

Evaluation skips the disabled Entries.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

port.desc:
Specify the Listen port. By default, SafeSquid listens on port 8080.

<1 - 65535>
Port value can be a positive integer between 1 and 65535

8080
Default value is 8080

ip.desc:
Specify the IP address to complete the socket definition. You may choose a specific IPv4 or IPv6 address.

Empty or Blank
All the IPv4 and IPv6 addresses of the host.

0.0.0.0
Listen to all IPv4 IPs only

::
Listen to all IPv6 IPs only

listen_flag.desc:
Choose additional bindings (roles) for this Socket.

You may select multiple options if you need.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (!profile).

ip.desc:
Specify an IP address assigned to the host system.

SafeSquid will bind the outgoing connection to this IP address thus effectively applying the desired routing for the connection.

prefetch.desc:
Use Prefetching to enhance user experience.

SafeSquid can analyze HTML pages, to identify links to embedded content, and initiate the fetch and cache process while still serving the initial HTML pages.

Create entries in the Prefetch Sub-Section set the logic for analyzing the HTML pages.

Enable Caching for using Prefetching effectively.

threads.desc:
Maximum concurrent threads that will be used for Pre-Fetching.

SafeSquid service must be restarted to effect any change in this setting.

Optional Values are 1-256.

queuesize.desc:
Specify the maximum size of the prefetch queue.

Each identified link is pushed to the bottom of the prefetch queue.

The links starting from the top of the queue are fetched, analyzed, and cached.

The newly identified links are ignored, if the queue is full.

Optional Values are from 1 to 256

hostlimit.desc:
Specify the maximum number of queued prefetches per host.

Prevent too many parallel fetches to the same host.

Optional Values are from 1 to 256

comment.desc: For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (!profile).

tag.desc:
Specify the HTML tag that should be analyzed for pre-fetchable URLs.


For example :A, img, link, script.

attribute.desc:
Specify the attribute of the HTML tag, holding the URL to be prefetched.

For eg: href, src,etc.

pattern.desc: Specify the regular expression to evaluate the URL discovered in the Tag Attribute. If the regular expression matches, the URL is logically expanded, and pushed into the prefetch queue.

maxsize.desc:
Specify the maximum size of the file to be prefetched.

Use suffix â€“ K, M, G, for Kilo Bytes, Mega Bytes, Giga Bytes

Hint: Set this to 0 for an unlimited size.

recursion.desc:
Set the Recursion limit to 0, or a higher positive integer.

Prefetched content is analyzed, to discover new prefetchable URLs.

Recursion limits this iteration.

Note: Setting to 0 causes links to be followed, indefinitely.

queue.appcontent: Add URL to prefetch queue

prefetch.desc:
Create list of Entries to implement your Prefetch Policies.

SafeSquid produces a virtual map of the tags discovered in a Web page.

SafeSquid evaluates the list for an entry applicable for each tag.

Evaluation begins with topmost entry, and sequentially iterates until first applicability match.

Evaluation ignores disabled entries.

Use Profiles, Name of the Tag, Tag Attributes, and Pattern of the Attribute to specify applicability.

Only Entries with both Name of the Tag, Tag Attributes, specified will be applicable.

SafeSquid uses the first applicable Entry and, skips the rest.

prefetch_queue.desc:
Add a popular URL into the prefetch queue.

The Prefetched content will be cached.

profiles.desc:
Use Access Profiles to setup your Profiled Internet Access policies.
Implement your policies, by creating a logical order of Entries.
Each Request within a connection, and the Response received from the remote web server:
  • is first evaluated against the Default Policies List of Entries,
  • and then aganst the Secondary Policies List of Entries.
After all Entries are tested:
  1. The Connection will be Blocked if the resultant Action is not set to Allow.
  2. The Resultant Connection's Profiles then determines the applicability of the Policy Entries in the other Configurable Sections.

defaults.desc:
Connections are tested against the Secondary Policies List after they are tested against the Default Policies List.
The Policies List of Entries is processed top-down for each request and response in a Connection.
Implement your Policies, by creating a logical order of Entries.
Each Entry consists of Rules for testing applicability.
An Entry is applicable only if a Request matches all the Rules of an Entry.
When an Entry is applicable:
  1. The corresponding set of Added Profiles, is appended to the Connection's Profiles
  2. The corresponding set of Removed Profiles, is deleted from the Connection's Profiles
  3. The corresponding Action is set against the Connection.
  4. The Request is now tested against subsequent Entry, based on the resulting state of modified Connection's Profiles

profile.desc:
Connections are tested against the Secondary Policies List after they are tested against the Default Policies List.
The Policies List of Entries is processed top-down for each request and response in a Connection.
Implement your Policies, by creating a logical order of Entries.
Each Entry consists of Rules for testing applicability.
An Entry is applicable only if a Request matches all the Rules of an Entry.
When an Entry is applicable:
  1. The corresponding set of Added Profiles, is appended to the Connection's Profiles
  2. The corresponding set of Removed Profiles, is deleted from the Connection's Profiles
  3. The corresponding Action is set against the Connection.
  4. The Request is now tested against subsequent Entry, based on the resulting state of modified Connection's Profiles

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profile_tracing.desc:
Enable or Disable Tracing of this entry

Select "Yes" to debug the application of entry using SafeSquid logs.

"Enable entry tracing" is useful if you wish to validate its application.

proxyhost.desc:
Leave this blank, if this configuration is not shared across multiple instances of SafeSquid.

Leave it blank to apply this entry to all your instances of SafeSquid.

Specify the hostname(s) of the instances, for which this entry should be applicable, if multiple instances share this configuration.

Mostly used in master-slave and cluster environments.

profiles.desc:
Specify the list of Profiles for which this entry should be applicable.

Leave it Blank, to ignore this applicability test.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of their Profile.

To avoid application of this entry to a connection that has a profile, use negation (!profile).

time_profiles.desc:
Specify the list of Time Profile(s) for which this entry should be applicable.

Leave it Blank, to ignore this applicability test.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has at-least one of the specified Time Profile(s).

To avoid application of this entry to a connection that has a Time Profile, use negation (!Weekday).

Go to Time Profiler to review, or define new Time Profiles.

user_groups.desc:
Specify the list of User Group(s), to which this entry is applicable.

Leave it Blank, to ignore this applicability test.

If one or more User Groups is/are specified, this entry will be applicable after it is determined, if user authentication is required. If user authentication is required, then this entry will be applicable only after successful user authentication.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has at-least one of the specified User Group(s).

To avoid application to a connection for specific User Group(s), use negation (!User Group).

Go to Access Restrictions to review or define new User Groups.

req_types.desc:
List of Request Types or application categories, to which this entry will be applicable.

The connection should have been already profiled to have one or more of these Request Types or application categories.

Use Negation "!", to check this entry only, when specified Request Types or application categories are not applied to the connection.

Leave it Blank to check this entry irrespective of applied Request Types or application categories.

If you set this to "Browsers,Skype,Webinar,!Safari", then this entry will be applicable to only those connections that have been profiled as Browsers, or Skype or Webinar, or not profiled as Safari.

web_categories.desc:
List of categories, to which this entry will be applicable.

The connection should have been already categorized to have one or more of these categories.

Use Negation "!", to check this entry only, when specified categories are not applied to the connection.

Leave it Blank to check this entry irrespective of applied categories.

If you set this to "Social,Chat,IM,!Porn ", then this entry will be applicable to only those connections that have been categorized as Social, or Chat, or IM, or not categorized as Porn.

res_types.desc:
List of Response Types or content categories, to which this entry will be applicable.

The connection should have been already profiled to have one or more of these Response Types or content categories.

Use Negation "!", to check this entry only, when specified Response Types or content categories are not applied to the connection.

Leave it Blank to check this entry irrespective of applied Response Types or content categories.

If you set this to "Image,Pdf,Audio,!Text,!Jpeg", then this entry will be applicable to only those connections that have been profiled as Image, or Pdf, or Audio, or not profiled as Text or Jpeg.

action.desc:
Specify action to enforce on matched connections.

ALLOW: Allow users to access.Default action. When action is allow SafeSquid uses applied profiles to do various filtering. Otherwise blocks access without doing further filtering.

DENY: Block access but allow users to bypass and access sites for couple of hours. You can configure bypass access to the users using access restrictions.

DO NOT BYPASS: Strictly Block access.

INHERIT: Apply previously applied action.

add_profiles.desc:
Specify the list of Profiles, to append to the connectionâ€™s existing Profiles, if the all applicability test rules match.

Subsequent applicable Entry may further modify the connectionâ€™s Profiles.

Define a new Profile(s), or Select previously defined Profile(s) from the drop-down menu to apply to the connection, if they match this entry.

When defining a new Profile, use terms that uniquely represent your needs.

You can use added profiles in Virus scanning, SSL inspection and other filtering sections.

remove_profiles.desc:
Select profiles to remove from connection when matches.

The connection should have been already profiled to have one or more of these profiles.

Use remove profiles adequately to ensure white-list profiles does not conflict with block profiles.

When a connection matches to block profile and as well white-list profile then your white-list entry should be configured with to remove block profile from connection.

Leave it Blank to ignore.

FALSE.desc: Select this to disable profile tracing.

TRUE.desc: Select this to enable profile tracing.

ALLOW.desc: Select this, if you want to allow requests or responses matching this policy

DENY.desc: Select, if you want to block requests or responses matching this policy. Will not block the requests or responses to those users who have allow bypass set from the access section.

INHERIT.desc: Select, if you want to apply the action based on previous profiles match up.

DO_NOT_BYPASS.desc: Select, if you want to strictly block the websites.

zero.desc: Enforce network traffic to be routed through an alternate outbound IP.

Bypass inspection of SSL/TLS encrypted traffic.
Tunnel Non-Browser applications to remote web servers.
Facilitate use of Client side SSL certificates for Digital Signature.

one.desc: Allow traffic to websites with self-signed certificates.

two.comment: BYPASS NO ISSUER CERT LOCALLY ERROR
two.value: BYPASS NO ISSUER CERT LOCALLY ERROR
two.desc: Bypass SSL errors for incomplete certificate chain due to missing issuer certificates.

zero.desc: Bypass scanning of request and response payloads with Clam Antivirus.

one.desc: Enforce scanning of request and response payloads with Clam Antivirus.

zero.desc: Bypass scanning of request and response payloads with Text Analyzer.
Enforce Bing safe search by Redirect unsafe Bing search request to safe Bing search request.

one.desc: Enforce Google safe search by Redirect unsafe Google search request to safe Google search request.

two.desc: Enforce YouTube safe Search by Redirect unsafe YouTube search request to safe YouTube search request.

three.desc: Enforce Yahoo safe search by Redirect unsafe Yahoo search request to safe Yahoo search request.

four.desc: Enforce DuckDuckGo safe search by Redirect unsafe DuckDuckGo search request to safe DuckDuckGo search request.

zero.desc:
Bypass image filtering for disabling content-based blocking. Intended to prevent false positives in content blocking, ensuring legitimate access is not incorrectly denied.
Use this bypass cautiously, as it could potentially allow sensitive or inappropriate content to pass through unchecked.

one.desc:
Enforce highest level of scrutiny for image scanning, designed to detect and block pornographic content with extreme precision.
Image filter blocks inappropriate images by analyzing the graphical content of an image, in real time.
Effective against surrogate websites known to serve such content.

zero.desc:
Allows all types of file uploads without restrictions.
Use this setting for environments where data sharing is unrestricted and the risk of sensitive data loss is considered low, or DLP is been taken care somewhere else in your network.

one.desc:
Blocks all file uploads to prevent potential data leaks.
Ideal for highly sensitive environments where the prevention of any unauthorized data transfer is critical.

two.desc: Permits the upload of Excel documents (.xls, .xlsx), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

three.desc: Permits the upload of Word documents (.doc, .docx), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

four.desc: Permits the upload of PowerPoint presentations (.ppt, .pptx), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

five.desc: Permits the upload of PDF files (.pdf), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

six.desc: Permits the upload of compressed files (.zip), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

seven.desc: Permits the upload of image files (e.g., .jpg, .png, .gif), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

zero.desc: Drop all cookies sent in Request and Response Headers, and thus prevent login.

Header Filtering policy inserts X-GoogApps: our_domain.com into response headers sent to the client.
Prevent use of personal account and force use of corporate email account for Google mail.

one.desc:
Header Filtering policy inserts YouTube-Restrict: Strict into request headers sent to YouTube.
Enforces YouTube's "Strict" restriction mode across our network, aiming to filter out potentially adult content and ensure a safer browsing environment.

two.desc:
Header Filtering policy inserts Content-Security-Policy: sandbox into response headers sent to the client.
Present a very minimalistic view of websites.
Prevent any form submission, all javascripts and background XHR.

three.desc:
Header Filtering policy inserts Content-Security-Policy: connect-src into response headers sent to the client.
Prevent javascripts from triggering cross-site background traffic.

zero.desc: Bypass enforcement of Elevated Privacy. Permit Third-Party transactions.

one.desc:
Prevent third-party cookies
Third-party cookies are often used by advertisers and tracking services to monitor user activity across multiple websites, potentially compromising user privacy.

two.desc: Prevent cookie exchange, hide referrer, and user-agent Third-party cookies are used for tracking users across multiple websites, while the HTTP(s) referrer and user-agent data can be exploited to identify and profile individuals.

zero.desc:
Enforces regulated download speeds for optimized network performance, prioritizing equitable access and preventing bandwidth hogging.
Useful in networks with slow internet speeds, ensuring that available bandwidth is fairly distributed among users for smoother online experiences.

one.desc: Enforces regulated on maximum number of bytes that can be downloaded for optimized network performance, prioritizing equitable access and preventing bandwidth hogging, useful in networks with slow internet speeds, ensuring that available bandwidth is fairly distributed among users for smoother online experiences.

two.desc: Enforces regulated upload speeds for optimized network performance, prioritizing equitable access and preventing bandwidth hogging, useful in networks with slow internet speeds, ensuring that available bandwidth is fairly distributed among users for smoother online experiences.

profilesdef.desc: Customize configuration to suit your internet access policies.

redirect.desc:
Create policies to redirect requests for a URL to another URL.

You may create redirection policies that intelligently fetch response from a desired URL, and serve it to the client.

Alternatively, you may create policies that respond with a HTTP 302 redirection that instructs the client to seek your suggested URL.

DECODEBEFORE.desc: Decode the URL before attempting to match it with the regular expression.

DECODEAFTER.desc: Decode the new URL after matching.

LOCATION.desc: Redirect if the URL is part of the location header.

URL.desc: Redirected if the URL is part of the actual request.

BOTH.desc: Redirect if the URL is part of either actual request or Location header.

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profiles.desc:
Specify the Profiles applicable for this entry.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has any one of the specified profiles.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of any applied profile.

To avoid application to a connection that has a profile, use negated profile (!profile).

url.desc:
Specify the requests to redirect.

This should be a valid PCRE (Perl Compatible Regular Expression).

Redirection occurs only if the requested URL matches this PCRE.

A typical URL is in the form "protocol://host/file".

redirect.desc:
Specify the URL to redirect the request to.

A typical URL is in the form "protocol://host/file".

If left blank, the request will neither be redirected to any URL nor be connected to the requested URL, thus leaving the request never served.

port.desc:
Specify the port to redirect the request to.

If left blank, the request will be redirected to the port available in the original request.

send302.desc:
If yes, a 302 redirect is issued; otherwise the new host is connected to directly and the new file is requested.

A 302 redirect should always be used when possible to ensure relative links and images are correct.

options.desc: Several options are available to control how the URL should be handled.

which.desc: Specify whether the URL to be redirected is the actual request from the user or part of the Location header returned by the requested site.

redirection.desc:
Create Entries to setup your URL Redirection Policies.

First entry applicable for a connection is used, skipping the rest.

Disabled Entries are ignored.

template.active: AgeURLMethodRequestsIPClient ID
